Award.AwardTitle: Granting Access to Mathematics and Science - Cohort II

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this project is to increase the number of highly qualified and capable students who are able to complete degrees in STEM majors by providing approximately 20 need-based scholarships at Bowling Green State University, Owens Community College, and Terra Community College. A variety of student support programs are designed, such as a 5-week summer bridge for entering students to prepare them for the rigors of college science and math courses; a tiered system of mentoring by peers and faculty; learning communities with monthly events that draw students and faculty together by merging academics and social networking; undergraduate research; and support and promotion of graduate and professional studies after completion of a baccalaureate degree. This project increases the graduation rate in mathematics and science of economically disadvantaged students and of under-represented women and ethnic minority students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The most important outcome of this project was the finding that meeting the financial need of under-represented minority (URM) and economically disadvantaged students who participate in a comprehensive support program are substantively more likely to complete an undergraduate degree in a STEM discipline within four years. This grant provided half of the funding for this project with the other half provided by a prior S-STEM grant, award #0850026.

Some students started in the project at a nearby community college as part of an NSF STEP grant project, SETGO. Other students started at a research university as a member of a comprehensive support program, Academic Investment in Mathematics and Science (AIMS).  Thirty-two students were awarded scholarships by spring term 2012 and could have graduated within four years during the funding period of this project. Of those students, 78% graduated within four years; 62.5% of the students who started at the community college graduated within four years and 88.2% of the students who started in the AIMS program at the research university graduated within four years. 50% (2 of 4) of the URM students who started at the community college graduated in four years and 80.0% of the URM students who started in the AIMS program graduated in four years. It is notable that all of these students are economically disadvantaged and qualified for relatively large amounts of financial aid based on their unmet financial need.

These graduation rates greatly exceed the national averages for similar students. Overall about 48% of students who start in a STEM major to earn a bachelor’s degree and 69% of students who start in a STEM major to earn an associate’s degree leave within six years without completing a STEM degree [Chen, X. and M. Soldner. (2013)]. The attrition numbers are higher for URM students: 65% of Black students who start out in a STEM bachelor’s degree program and 78% of Black students who start out in a STEM associate’s degree program switch out of STEM within six years. Note that these numbers are for attrition without any graduation even in six years whereas the numbers given above for this project are four-year graduation rates.

Indeed, these four-year graduation rates for AIMS students who received GRAMS scholarships are even higher than were previously reported for regular AIMS students. Regular AIMS students receive smaller amounts of financial aid of $2000-4500 annually. GRAMS students received scholarships corresponding to the amount of their unmet financial need to a maximum of $10,000 per year and in order to maximize the impact of the grant, students were selected who had the greatest unmet financial need, since these students were deemed most likely to realize the financial benefit of these scholarships. The mean annual scholarship amount was approximately $8,000 and more than half of the recipients received the maximum scholarship amount indicating a very high level of financial need and were therefore in an economically disadvantaged Social-Economic Status (SES). This suggests that providing financial aid to help address this financial need can further increase student academic success above the improvement realized by a robust and comprehensive program of multiple support mechanisms.

Further analysis of these data and other comparison data from the host university and others is being conducted to discern more about the full measure of this impact and to better understand all of the factors that account for the outcomes.

Chen, X. and M. Soldner. (2013). "STEM Attrition: College Students’ Paths into and out of STEM Fields. Statistical Analysis Report." U.S. Department of Education, National Center for Education Statistics, Retrieved 14 June 2016, http://nces.ed.gov/pubs2014/2014001rev.pdf.
